title: What's the meaning of your name? - Quora

response.answer_text: My given name Deepthi means brilliance. It is based on the Sanskrit “Deepa" for lamp, or a source of light. A more detailed meaning of my name that ties in with the lamp symbolism, is as the brilliant light of knowledge that dispels the darkness of ignorance. Do I identify with the meaning of my name? I realize that the more condensed interpretation is ironically apt, when I stop to ponder it. Usually that happens when prompted by a question like the one on this thread. My strongest feeling about my name is one of relief: that it carries no connotations of chastity. I would not want my private behavior effectively broadcast as my identifying trait. As I see it, explicitly branding a woman “not promiscuous” is just begging the question. I’m actually happier with the longer interpretation - I see it as inspirational. Not that I think of myself as brilliant (!!!) but I’m very interested in Astronomy, and have taught it at the college level. It just so happens that I am interested in unusually luminous stars like Eta Carinae, and in concentrations of super massive (and thus brilliant) stars, such as the Westerlund 1 super cluster.  New Image of Super Cluster Westerlund 1 This interest in hypergiant stars has nothing to do with my name* — I'm fascinated by the mere fact of their existence against many destabilizing influences. I have always been fascinated by how theoretical evolutionary tracks of very massive stars “loop around”, essentially showing the SAME luminosity during different times in their lives!  http://inspirehep.net/record/1250248/plots My strangest wish is to die when Eta Carinae is observed to go hypernova. Hopefully people close to me will remember the confluence of events.  Famous Hubble star explosion is expanding, new animation reveals *Deepthi Amarasuriya's answer to What is the one thing that made you the person you are today?

My full name is “Spencer Alexander McDaniel.” I have always thought that it is a particularly impressive-sounding name, especially if you know what it means. When you trace my first, middle, and last names all the way back to their etymological roots, my full name means: “Apportioner of Goods, Defender of Man, Son of ‘God Is My Judge.’” Spencer My first name, Spencer, is certainly the least impressive-sounding of the three names in terms of its etymological meaning. It is a shortened form of the English word dispenser, which, in the Early Modern Period, referred to a person who apportioned and distributed goods. Thus, the name Spencer originally arose as an occupational surname, just like Baker, Miller, Smith, Tyler, Cooper, Wright, and so forth. The famed Elizabethan English poet Edmund Spenser (lived c. 1553 – 1599), the author of the epic poem The Faerie Queene, was among the people who bore the name when it was mainly only used as a surname. Spencer did not become a common given name until around the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. The name reached the peak of its popularity in the 1990s, around the time when I was born.  ABOVE: Portrait of Edmund Spenser, the author of The Faerie Queene Alexander My middle name, Alexander, is a Latinized form of the ancient Greek name Ἀλέξανδρος (Aléxandros), which comes from the Ancient Greek verb ἀλέξω (aléxō), which means “I defend,” plus ἀνδρός (andrós), the singular genitive form of the noun ἀνήρ (anḗr), meaning “man.” Thus, the name means “Defender of Man.” The name Alexandros, interestingly, is first attested as the name of the king of the city of Wilusa (Troy) in Asia Minor (modern-day Turkey), who sealed a treaty in around 1280 BC with Muwatalli II, the king of the Hittites. The name is transliterated in the treaty into ancient Luwian as Alaksandu. Thus, my middle name actually can be traced all the way back to the Bronze Age.  ABOVE: Photograph of the Alaksandu treaty In the Iliad, an ancient Greek epic poem that was probably composed in around the eighth century BC, Alexandros is another name for Paris, a character in the epic who is one of the sons of King Priamos of Troy. As a result of Alexandros’s prominence in the Iliad, the name Alexandros was always a relatively common name in ancient Greece. Nonetheless, the name was greatly popularized by King Alexandros III of Makedonia—the man most commonly known in English as “Alexander the Great.” Starting during Alexander’s lifetime (356 – 323 BC) and continuing throughout the rest of ancient Greek history, Alexandros remained one of the most common names in the Hellenistic world. Eventually, the name entered into Latin and the Latinized form Alexander became a very popular Roman name as well. It was the Latin form of the name that eventually became common in English. Famous people named “Alexander” in modern times have included the Founding Father of the United States Alexander Hamilton (lived 1755 or 1757 – 1804) and the Scottish-born inventor Alexander Graham Bell (lived 1847 – 1922).  ABOVE: Third-century BC Greek marble statue of Alexander the Great McDaniel My last name is really unusual because it is an Anglicization of the Scottish clan name MacDòmhnaill, meaning “son of Dòmhnaill,” but the Scottish name Dòmhnaill has mistakenly been conflated with the English name Daniel, which comes from Δανιήλ, the Ancient Greek transliteration of the Biblical Hebrew name דָּנִיאֵל (Dānî’ēl), which means “God is My Judge.” This is, of course, the name of the hero Daniel in the Book of Daniel from the Hebrew Bible. This name, in turn, is probably a corruption of the even older ancient Canaanite name Dān’ēl, which was the name of a famous Canaanite culture hero. Dān’ēl is mentioned in the incomplete Epic of Aqhat, which was discovered inscribed on a clay tablet from the ancient Canaanite city of Ugarit that was probably originally written in the fourteenth century BC. A portion of my last name, then, can be traced back to the Bronze Age as well. If you translate the whole name McDaniel from its roots in both Scottish Gaelic and Biblical Hebrew, my full last name means “Son of ‘God Is My Judge.’”  ABOVE: Photograph of a clay tablet from Ugarit containing a portion of the Epic of Aqhat Of course, the Scottish name Dòmhnaill actually comes from the even earlier reconstructed Proto-Celtic name *Dubnowalos, which comes from a combination of the Proto-Celtic words *dubnos, meaning “world,” and *walos, meaning “prince.” The name therefore literally means “World-Prince.” Therefore, if you un-Anglicize my last name and go back to the original Scottish surname, the name actually means “Son of the World-Prince.” Amusingly, Dòmhnaill is also the source of the English name Donald. The surnames MacDonald and McDonald are both Anglicizations of MacDòmhnaill, just like McDaniel. The name of the popular American fast food restaurant McDonald’s therefore means “Belonging to the Son of the World-Prince.” Etymology can make even the name of a popular fast food restaurant sound terrifying.  ABOVE: Photograph of the McDonald’s “Golden Archs.” The name McDonald is an alternative Anglicization of the Scottish clan name MacDòmhnaill, which means “Son of the World-Prince.”
